readingPart.reading:
anusesophagusliver
cecumgallbladderpancreas
colonileumpharynx
duodenumjejunumsigmoid colon

questionContent.questionText:
1. consists of ascending, transverse, descending, and sigmoid sections [colon]

2. small sac under the liver; stores bile [gallbladder]

3. ﬁrst part of the large intestine [cecum]

4. end of the digestive tract opening to the outside of the body [anus]

5. second part of the small intestine [jejunum]

6. tube connecting the throat to the stomach [esophagus]

7. third part of the small intestine [ileum]

8. large organ in the RUQ; secretes bile, stores sugar, produces blood proteins [liver]

9. throat [pharynx]

10. lowest part of the colon [sigmoid colon]

11. ﬁrst part of the small intestine [duodenum]

12. organ under the stomach; produces insulin and digestive enzymes [pancreas ]

instructions.instructions: Match the following digestive system structures with their meanings below.

questionContent.questionText:
Saliva is created by the... 

  1. [SALIVARY GLANDS]

Food enters the...

  1. [ORAL CAVITY]
  2. [PHARYNX]
  3. [ESOPHAGUS]
  4. [STOMACH]

Bile is created by the...

  1. [LIVER]

Bile is stored in the...

  1. [GALLBLADDER]

Enzymes are created by the...

  1. [PANCREAS]

Parts of the small intestine include...

  1. [DUODENUM]
  2. [JEJUNUM]
  3. [ILEUM]

Parts of the large intestine include...

  1. [CECUM]
  2. [ASCENDING COLON]
  3. [TRANSVERSE COLON]
  4. [DESCENDING COLON]
  5. [SIGMOID COLON]
  6. [RECTUM]

Feces leaves the body...

  1. [ANUS]

instructions.instructions: Correctly sequence the pathway of food through the gastrointestinal tract, starting at the beginning of the tract. The terms you will need are listed in the dropdowns.

questionContent.questionText: Microscopic projections in the walls of the small intestine:

readingPart.reading: Papillae are nipple-like projections in the tongue where taste buds are located, and rugae are folds in the mucous membrane of the stomach and hard palate.

questionContent.questionText: salivary gland near the ear:

readingPart.reading: The submandibular gland is under the lower jaw, and the sublingual gland is under the tongue.

questionContent.questionText: ring of muscle at the end of the stomach:

readingPart.reading: The uvula is soft tissue hanging from the soft palate, and the lower esophageal sphincter is a ring of muscle between the esophagus and stomach.

questionContent.questionText: soft, inner section of a tooth:

readingPart.reading: Dentin is the hard part of the tooth directly under the enamel and in the root, and enamel is the hard, outermost part of the tooth composing the crown.

questionContent.questionText: Chemical that speeds up reactions and helps digest foods:

readingPart.reading: A triglyceride is a large fat molecule, and an amino acid is a substance produced when proteins are digested.

questionContent.questionText: pigment released with bile:

readingPart.reading: Glycogen is animal starch that is produced in liver cells from sugar, and melena is dark, tarry stools.

questionContent.questionText: hormone produced by endocrine cells of the pancreas:

readingPart.reading: Amylase and lipase are digestive enzymes produced by the exocrine cells of the pancreas.

questionContent.questionText: rhythm-like contraction of the muscles in the walls of the gastrointestinal tract:

readingPart.reading: Deglutition is swallowing, and mastication is chewing.

questionContent.questionText: breakdown of large fat globules:

readingPart.reading: Absorption is the passage of materials through the walls of the small intestine into the bloodstream, and anabolism is the process of building up proteins in a cell (protein synthesis).

questionContent.questionText: pointed, dog-like tooth medial to premolars:

readingPart.reading: An incisor is one of the four front teeth in the dental arch (not pointed or like a dog’s tooth), and a molar is any of three large teeth just behind (distal to) the two premolar teeth.

instructions.instructions: Select the term that ﬁts the given deﬁnition. You should be able to deﬁne the other terms as well!

questionContent.questionText:
1. Labi/o and cheil/o mean [lip]

2. Gloss/o and lingu/o mean [tongue]

3. Or/o and stomat/o mean [mouth]

4. Dent/i and odont/o mean [tooth]

5. Lapar/o and celi/o mean [abdomen]

6. Gluc/o and glyc/o mean [sugar]

7. Lip/o, steat/o, and adip/o mean [fat]

8. The sufﬁxes -iasis and -osis mean [abnormal condition]

9. Chol/e and bil/i mean [gall/bile]

10. Resection and -ectomy mean [removal/excision]

1. removal of a salivary gland [sialadenectomy]

2. pertaining to the throat [pharyngeal]

3. hernia of the rectum [rectocele]

4. enlargement of the liver [hepatomegaly]

5. surgical repair of the roof of the mouth [palatoplasty]

6. after meals [postprandial]

7. visual examination of the anal and rectal region [proctoscopy]

8. study of the cause (of disease) [etiology]

9. incision of the common bile duct [choledochotomy]

10. pertaining to teeth and cheek [dentibuccal]

11. disease condition of the small intestine [enteropathy]

12. new opening between the common bile duct and the jejunum [choledochojejunostomy]

13. pertaining to surrounding the anus [perianal]

14. new opening from the colon to the outside of the body [colostomy]

15. under the lower jaw [submandibular]

16. pertaining to the face [facial]

instructions.instructions: Build medical terms based on the given deﬁnitions.

readingPart.reading:
colorectal surgeonnephrologistperiodontist
endodontistoral surgeonproctologist
gastroenterologistorthodontisturologist

questionContent.questionText:
1. treats disorders of the anus and rectum [proctologist]

2. operates on the organs of the urinary tract [urologist]

3. straightens teeth [orthodontist]

4. performs root canal therapy [endodontist]

5. operates on the mouth and teeth [oral surgeon]

6. treats kidney disorders [nephrologist]

7. diagnoses and treats gastrointestinal disorders [gastroenterologist]

8. treats gum disease [periodontist]

9. operates on the intestinal tract [colorectal surgeon ]

instructions.instructions: Match the following doctors or dentists with their specialties.

questionContent.questionText:
1. inﬂammation of the appendix [appendicitis]

2. inﬂammation of the large intestine [colitis]

3. inﬂammation of the passageway from the throat to the stomach [esophagitis]

4. inﬂammation of the membrane surrounding the abdomen [peritonitis]

5. inﬂammation of the gallbladder [cholecystitis]

6. inﬂammation of the third part of the small intestine [ileitis]

7. inﬂammation of the pancreas [pancreatitis]

8. inﬂammation of the gums [gingivitis]

9. inﬂammation of the liver [hepatitis]

10. inﬂammation of the mouth [stomatitis]

11. inﬂammation of the salivary gland [sialadenitis]

12. inﬂammation of the small and large intestines [enterocolitis]

instructions.instructions: Build medical terms to describe the following inﬂammations.

readingPart.reading:
anastomosisgluconeogenesismesentery
biliaryglycogenolysismucosa
defecationhyperbilirubinemiaparenteral
cheilitishyperglycemiaportal vein

questionContent.questionText:
1. high level of blood sugar [hyperglycemia]

2. inﬂammation of the lip [cheilitis]

3. pertaining to administration of medicines and ﬂuid other than by mouth [parenteral]

4. mucous membrane [mucosa]

5. expulsion of feces from the body through the anus [defecation]

6. breakdown (conversion) of starch to sugar [glycogenolysis]

7. fan-like membrane that connects the small intestine to the abdominal wall [mesentery]

8. large vessel that takes blood to the liver from the intestines [portal vein]

9. new surgical connection between structures or organs [anastomosis]

10. pertaining to bile ducts [biliary]

11. process of forming new sugar from proteins and fats [gluconeogenesis]

12. high levels of a bile pigment in the bloodstream [hyperbilirubinemia ]

instructions.instructions: Match the listed terms with the meanings that follow.

questionContent.questionText:
1. passage of bright red blood from the rectum [hematochezia]

2. lack of appetite [anorexia]

3. fat in the feces [steatorrhea]

4. black, tarry stools; feces containing digested blood [melena]

5. abnormal accumulation of ﬂuid in the abdomen [ascites]

6. rumbling noises produced by gas in the gastrointestinal tract [borborygmi]

7. gas expelled through the anus [flatus]

8. an unpleasant sensation in the stomach and a tendency to vomit [nausea]

9. loose, watery stools [diarrhea]

10. difﬁculty in passing stools (feces) [constipation]

11. difﬁculty in swallowing [dysphagia]

12. gas expelled from the stomach through the mouth [eructation]

instructions.instructions: Give the names of the following gastrointestinal signs or symptoms based on their descriptions.

readingPart.reading: yellow-orange coloration of the skin and other tissues (hyperbilirubinemia)

prompt.text: List three ways in which a patient can become jaundiced:

readingPart.reading:
a. any liver disease (hepatopathy—such as cirrhosis, hepatoma, or hepatitis), so that bilirubin is not processed into bile and cannot be excreted in feces

b. obstruction of bile flow, so that bile and bilirubin are not excreted and accumulate in the bloodstream

c. excessive hemolysis leading to overproduction of bilirubin and high levels in the bloodstream

prompt.text: What does it mean when a disease is described as idiopathic?

instructions.instructions: Write short answers for the following questions.

readingPart.reading:
achalasiacolorectal cancerherpetic stomatitis
anal fistulaCrohn disease (Crohn's)oral leukoplakia
aphthous stomatitisdental cariespancreatic cancer
colonic polypsesophageal cancerperiodontal disease

questionContent.questionText:
1. Mr. Jones, a smoker and heavy drinker, complained of dysphagia in recent months. A longstanding condition of Barrett esophagus resulted in his malignant condition.

Diagnosis: [esophageal cancer ]

2. An abnormal tube-like passageway near his anus caused Mr. Rosen’s proctalgia. His doctor performed surgery to close off the abnormality.

Diagnosis: [anal ﬁstula]

3. Carol’ s  dentist informed her that the enamel of three teeth was damaged by bacteria-producing acid.

Diagnosis: [dental caries]

4. Paola’s symptoms of chronic diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and fever led her doctor to suspect that she suffered from an inﬂammatory bowel disease affecting the distal portion of her ileum. The doctor prescribed steroid drugs to heal her condition.

Diagnosis: [Crohn disease (Crohn’s)]

5. Mr. Hart learned that his colonoscopy showed the presence of small benign growths protruding from the mucous membrane of his large intestine.

Diagnosis: [colonic polyps]

6. During a routine dental checkup, Dr. Friedman discovered white plaques on Mr. Longo’s buccal mucosa. He advised Mr. Longo, who was a chronic smoker and heavy drinker, to have these precancerous lesions removed.

Diagnosis: [oral leukoplakia]

7. Every time Carl had a stressful time at work, he developed a fever blister (cold sore) on his lip, resulting from reactivation of a previous viral infection. His doctor told him that there was no treatment 100% effective in preventing the reappearance of these lesions.

Diagnosis: [herpetic stomatitis]

8. Mr. Green had a biopsy of a neoplastic lesion in his descending colon. The pathology report indicated a malignancy. A partial colectomy was necessary.

Diagnosis: [colorectal cancer]

9. Small ulcers (canker sores) appeared on Diane’s gums. They were painful and annoying. 

Diagnosis: [aphthous stomatitis]

10. Sharon’s failure to ﬂoss her teeth and remove dental plaque regularly led to development of gingivitis and pyorrhea. Her dentist advised consulting a specialist who could treat her condition.

Diagnosis: [periodontal disease]

11. Imaging tests revealed a tumor in a section of Mr. Smith’s  pancreas. His physician told him that since it had not spread, he could hope for a cure with surgery. He had a pancreatoduodenectomy (Whipple procedure), which was successful.

Diagnosis: [pancreatic cancer]

12. Mr. Clark complained of pain during swallowing. His physician explained that the pain was caused by a failure of muscles in his lower esophagus to relax during swallowing.

Diagnosis: [achalasia ]

instructions.instructions: Select from the list of pathologic conditions to make a diagnosis.

readingPart.reading:
cholecystolithiasis (gallstones)hemorrhoidspancreatitis
cirrhosishiatal herniapeptic ulcer
diverticulosisileusulcerative colitis
dysenteryintussusceptionviral hepatitis
esophageal varicesirritable bowel syndromevolvulus

questionContent.questionText:
1. protrusion of the upper part of the stomach through the diaphragm [hiatal hernia]

2. painful, inﬂamed intestines caused by bacterial infection [dysentery]

3. swollen, twisted veins in the rectal region [hemorrhoids]

4. open sore or lesion of the mucous membrane of the stomach or duodenum [peptic ulcer]

5. loss of peristalsis [ileus]

6. twisting of the intestine on itself [volvulus]

7. swollen, varicose veins on the surface of the distal portion of the esophagus [esophageal varices]

8. abnormal outpouchings in the intestinal wall [diverticulosis]

9. chronic inﬂammation of the colon with destruction of its inner surface [ulcerative colitis]

10. telescoping of the intestines [intussusception]

11. inﬂammation of the liver caused by type A, type B, or type C virus [viral hepatitis]

12. inﬂammation of the pancreas [pancreatitis]

13. calculi in the sac that stores bile [cholecystolithiasis (gallstones)]

14. chronic degenerative liver disease with scarring resulting from alcoholism or infectious hepatitis [cirrhosis]

15. gastrointestinal symptoms (diarrhea or constipation, abdominal pain, bloating) with no evidence of structural abnormalities [irritable bowel syndrome]

instructions.instructions: Match the following pathologic diagnoses with their deﬁnitions

questionContent.questionText:
1. membrane (peritoneal fold) that holds the intestines together: mes[entery]

2. removal of the gallbladder: [cholecyst]ectomy

3. black or dark brown, tarry stools containing blood: mel[ena]

4. high levels of pigment in the blood (jaundice): hyper[bilirubinemia]

5. pertaining to under the tongue: sub[lingual]

6. twisting of the intestine on itself: vol[vulus]

7. organ under the stomach that produces insulin and digestive enzymes: pan[creas]

8. lack of appetite: an[orexia]

9. swollen, twisted veins in the rectal region:  [hemorrh]oids

10. new connection between two previously unconnected tubes: ana[stomosis]

11. absence of acid in the stomach: a[chlorhydria]

12. return of solids and ﬂuids to the mouth from the stomach: gastro[esophageal reflux] disease

13. removal of soft tissue hanging from the roof of the mouth: [uvul]ectomy

14. formation of stones: [litho]genesis.

instructions.instructions: Complete the following terms from their meanings given below.
